text: Admiral, we have any ships to go to the south. It's a trap. You heard it from the man here first. That's our trap. That's kind of the nature of our brains with respect to trading. There are a lot of traps that are very easy to find your way into. And we all will experience these to different degrees. Now, one of the main things is to do your best and learn from these potential circumstances before you go through them yourself so that you have a little bit of an idea before you get too far into the weeds. So cognitive biases, believe it or not, we as human decision makers are literally riddled with cognitive biases. These are just some of them from my website. You can pop on, go look through it, your leisure. But there are some of these that are really, really dangerous. So things like the disposition effect is one that you have to be aware of. This is where we have a tendency to cut winning trades too short and let losers run, which is coupled with something called loss a version. Confirmation bias is another really, really important one. This is where we focus more so on information that confirms what we want to see and not what the objective reality might be. Hindsight bias, really important. Hindsight bias is when things seem ever so clear when we're looking at stuff in the rear view mirror, meaning stuff that has happened

The other thing is through exposure therapy. The way that works is let's say that you think 100 is a lot of money still. And you put on a trade, you lose 100, and it's really, really painful.
